markdownRemark.html:
I have seen many people struggling to make Kafka work on their machine, sometimes because of very weird setup configuration arcanes (mostly on Windows huh). So here is a little guide to set up a running service in order to play around with Kafka on your computer.

We will be using Docker as it helps reproductibility. Basically, we will be using an "image" of a working Kafka service and run it on your computer, and Docker is the layer between this image and your OS.

Disclaimer : this is by no means a production-level setup ! It is just meant to help students install Kafka on their computers.

1. Install Docker

Go to https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-windows/install/ and follow the instructions corresponding to your OS. You might have to create an account to download Docker Desktop if you are on Windows.

Please be careful when installing Docker, and follow all instructions properly. If next steps do not work as expected, you probably messed up when installing.

2. Start kafka

Simply type in the command line:

docker run -p 2181:2181 -p 9092:9092 --env ADVERTISED_HOST=localhost --env ADVERTISED_PORT=9092 spotify/kafka

It should download the Kafka Docker image from Docker Hub, and then run it.

3. Using Kafka

Because you are using Kafka through a Docker image, you do not have access to all the kafka-*.sh script files usually used in tutorials. A solution is to programmatically access Kafka, for instance with kafka-python.

For instance, you can create topics like this:

from kafka.admin import KafkaAdminClient, NewTopic
admin_client = KafkaAdminClient(bootstrap_servers="localhost:9092")

topic_list = []
topic_list.append(NewTopic(name="example_topic", num_partitions=1, replication_factor=1))
admin_client.create_topics(new_topics=topic_list, validate_only=False)

As for the rest, just follow kafka-python's documentation.

The end

This is yet another demonstration of the power of Docker for reproductibility. I've seen many teachers struggle to install software on students' computers. In many case, Docker might be what you are looking for !

frontmatter.title: Running a Kafka service simply on local using Docker
